headline: Opinion: What does it mean to be Canadian? Ask the Dutch | Edmonton Journal
context: The recent whirlwind of developments in the United States including the issue of tariffs and the threats to our sovereignty, has challenged our Canadian identity and indeed the very future of Canada itself. Never has the question “what it means to be a Canadian?” been more top of mind.

If you are in need of a boost of national pride or a reminder of what being a Canadian really means, just ask a “liberated” Dutch person. Or, any Dutch person who immigrated to Canada for that matter. The response may surprise you.

annotations.paragraph: Eighty years ago this May, the Canadian Army liberated the Netherlands from the brutal German occupation, helping bring the Second World War to an end. For five long years, the Dutch endured a dark and seemingly hopeless period. The German Army appeared unbeatable, and their brutality knew no limits. Any form of resistance meant instant execution or imprisonment. Infiltrators were everywhere, and no one could be trusted. Intense fear hung in the air, and as the years passed, food and supplies grew ever scarce. Thousands had already died, and thousands more were on the verge of starvation during the winter of 1945, which was reported to be one of the coldest in years.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context about Canada's role in liberating the Netherlands, relevant to Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: And then came the Canadians! Who were these brave young men who exhibited such bravery and determination? Who was this army from a country unknown, to take on this hardened and increasingly desperate German war machine — the most formidable ever to dominate Europe? Such were the questions immediately asked by the astonished and oppressed Dutch people.
annotations.reason: Highlights the perception of Canadians by the Dutch, relevant to the theme of Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: Everything was on the line. In the course of several months, over 7,600 soldiers died as the Canadian Army moved through the flat, unprotected Dutch countryside, village by village, town by town, region by region. But advance they did, and the Dutch people took notice — not only because of their courage and fighting skills, but because of traits before unseen — kindness, generosity and a spirit of humility.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context and examples of Canadian traits that contribute to the main premise of Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: These traits were in total contrast to the cruelty, brutality and superiority of their German oppressors. The Dutch people responded with overwhelming joy and immense gratitude. The incredibly positive impression made by the Canadian Army was also a contributing factor as to why so many Dutch people chose Canada as their new home, just a few years later.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the impact of Canadian traits on Dutch perceptions and immigration, relevant to the theme of Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: No event defines the bond between two countries like the Liberation of the Netherlands by the Canadian Army in the Second World War. Even today, a Canadian visiting the Netherlands will experience complete strangers coming up to them and thanking them for what Canada did in 1945.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights the lasting bond and gratitude between Canada and the Netherlands, relevant to the article's exploration of Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: Though time has passed, Dutch people continue to ask themselves: Why did these young men from a country far away, come here to fight, to die, and liberate us from our neighbours?
annotations.reason: This paragraph raises a question that underscores the mystery and admiration surrounding Canadian actions, relevant to the theme of identity.

annotations.paragraph: To Canadians, the answer is duty and a commitment to fight for freedom. But to the Dutch, with their deep European history, the answer remains a mystery and the cause for gratitude and celebration. Every school-aged child in the Netherlands learns about the Liberation and the role the Canadian Army played. Every Canadian soldier’s grave is tended to each year by schoolchildren. And every year, the Dutch celebrate the Liberation and give thanks to Canada for securing their freedom.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the enduring gratitude and educational impact in the Netherlands, relevant to the article's focus on Canadian identity.

annotations.paragraph: On May 4, Edmontonians will have the opportunity to experience this gratitude firsthand with the Remembrance and Gratitude Commemoration of the Liberation, in Light Horse Park, 10324-85 Avenue, at 12 p.m.

annotations.paragraph: This event is jointly hosted by the South Alberta Light Horse Regiment, the Dutch Canadian Club and many liberated Dutch-Canadians. Every Edmontonian, Albertan and Canadian is invited to attend and encouraged to recognize what it means to be Canadian.
